hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A portrait of Rabindranath Tagore against the backdrop of a globe, publiches by Print & Block Concern, Calcuttal. (gs)
ffff Künstler/Autor: Dhirey das [Signatur im Bild]

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It is perhaps fitting that Tagore—whose own philosophy of internationalism and cosmopolitanism lends itself to this—is shown with a large terrestrial globe marked with the numerous continents (clearly named), his face and body unfortunately blocking “Africa,” almost as if at least Dhiren Das (the artist) and the publisher thought that that continent was insignificant for Tagore’s global ecumenism. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The map of India is necessary of course because its presence in her visual persona allows Mother India to be distinguished from the numerous other Hindu goddesses whose calendar art incarnations she otherwise resembles. At the same time, prints like Hind-Mata appear to suggest that it is the mother’s body more than the geo-body of the nation that is important for citizen-viewers to focus upon as they reflect upon this composite image of India as a “carto-graphed” mother/goddess. In the process, borders and boundaries—the very sine qua non of normative state cartography—are transformed to accommodate the mother’s body, in some cases even completely disappearing to allow for the free flow or her saree, her hair or her limbs. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
related literature: Menon, V.P. 1956. The Story of the Integration of the Indian States. New York: Macmillan. (gs)
related literature: Nair, P. Thankappan. 1987. Indian National Songs and Symbols. Calcutta: Firma KLM Pvt. Ltd, pp. 74-97. (gs)
related literature: Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2010. The Goddess and the Nation. Mapping Mother India. London: Duke University Press. (gs)
